awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Large-Scale Computation of the Phonon Boltzmann Transport Equation
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET-1250215
PI: Sandip Mazumder, Ohio State University


The inability to remove heat efficiently is currently one of the major stumbling blocks towards further miniaturization and advancement of electronic and optoelectronic devices. Overheating is one of the most common causes of device failure. The characteristic dimension of an electronic device, such as a transistor, could range anywhere from few tens of nanometers to few tens of micrometers. At these scales, experiments are difficult to perform and modeling provides a means to better understand heat transport. Heat conduction in semiconductor materials is dominated by phonons. At the length scales of relevance, phonon transport can be effectively modeled using the Boltzmann Transport Equation for phonons. This project will develop a powerful simulation framework that makes use of heterogeneous computer platforms for multi-level parallelization and solution of the phonon Boltzmann Transport Equation for the prediction of heat transport in semiconductor materials over a range of length scales spanning all the way from nanometers to millimeters. Estimates indicate that such computations will require ~1017 floating point operations (i.e., peta-scale computing and beyond). The project goal will be accomplished using three means: (1) development of new approximate formulations of the Boltzmann Transport Equation that hybridize discrete ordinates, spherical harmonics and Monte Carlo methods to reduce computational effort (number of flops), (2) development of tools for automatic multi-level (multi-cores, graphical processing units and central processing units) parallelization of sequential Fortran90 or C codes that solve partial differential equations on unstructured meshes, and (3) adaptation of the automatic parallelization tools to solution of the Boltzmann Transport Equation by subsequent investigation and fine-grain refinement of the underlying numerical algorithms.

The research will pave the way for simulation-driven discovery of new material systems being used in applications such as thermo-electric energy conversion, Peltier cooling, solid-state sensing, and semiconductor lasers. From a computer science standpoint, while significant progress has been made on multi-level parallelization of codes that use structured meshes, the proposed research on unstructured mesh computations, being the first of its kind, will have unprecedented impact in all scientific computation disciplines that employ unstructured meshes. These include materials modeling, applied mechanics, computational fluid dynamics, and computational electromagnetics. The project will have impact on education through engagement of students at two levels: (a) high school students within the local area and participating in Ohio supercomputer center's summer programs and (b) graduate students through advanced numerical methods courses that will introduce them to advanced parallel computing using a variety of platforms (clusters, multi-cores, and graphical processing units).

por.por_cntn:
Characteristic length scales in modern-day electronic and optoelectronic devices range between 10-1000 nm. The primary carriers of heat in crystalline semiconductor materials are lattice vibrational waves known as phonons. The mean free path of phonons is frequency dependent and for some frequencies, can exceed the characteristic length scale. For example, the average mean free path of acoustic phonons in silicon is ~300 nm. When the mean free path is larger than the characteristic length scale, the phonons are said to be in non-equilibrium. Non-equilibrium thermal transport in crystalline solids cannot be described adequately by the Fourier law of heat conduction. One way to model such transport is to solve the Boltzmann Transport Equation (BTE) for phonons. The BTE is a seven-dimensional partial differential equation, and its solution is challenging.

The objective of this project was to develop a state-of-the-art scalable parallel solver for the phonon BTE that will enable prediction of thermal transport in realistic three-dimensional heterostructures, such as field-effect transistors. To accomplish this goal, the project was split into three sub-tasks. The first task was to parallelize an existing serial BTE solver using state-of-the-art paradigms in computational science. The second task was to enhance the BTE based thermal transport model to include multiple materials and material interfaces, as prevalent in semiconductor devices. The third task was to lay the foundation for extracting phonon scattering (or relaxation) time-scales from recently conducted pump-probe experiments. To this end, simulations of the exact conditions of a time-domain thermo-reflectance (TDTR) experiment were carried out using the BTE solver, and methods for extracting the effective thermal conductivity, and thermal conductivity accumulation and suppression functions were developed.

Notable technical accomplishments of the project include (1) demonstration of the parallel BTE solver for prediction of spatio-temporal temperature and heat flux in large-scale three-dimensional semiconductor heterostructures—calculations that involved 9.7 billion unknowns (3 orders of magnitude larger than previously reported studies), (2) development and demonstration of hybrid ballistic-diffusive solvers for the BTE in order to improve computational efficiency, and (3) demonstration of the solver for the simulation of TDTR experiments—a study that represents the first of its kind, and has been deemed by this community as a major challenge.

The project has resulted in 3 thesis/dissertations, 4 journal publications, and 4 peer-reviewed conference publications thus far. A few more are in the pipeline. Several presentations and abstracts were also generated. Five graduate students (2 in Mechanical Engineering and 3 in Computer Science) were trained as part of this project. The PI also developed an online course on numerical solution of partial differential equations, which is currently on offer through the nanoHUB portal, and currently has 30 enrollees.

The computational algorithms developed during this project have broader impact outside of the core discipline since the BTE is the fundamental equation that drives all transport phenomena. Such areas include radiation (photon) transport, electron transport, and molecular transport (flow) in rarified (large Knudsen number) regimes.
